div.p: ANTONIO: None of us wants to lose what we value. I know I sure don't.
ANTONIO: But the experience you've just gone through is much closer to real life than many of us would like to think.
ANTONIO: When we make high‚Äêrisk alcohol or drug choices, we can lose a lot, just as you imagined in the activity.
ANTONIO: But, unlike the activity, in real life we don't get to choose which things we will lose. The first thing to go might be the one thing we cherish most.
ANTONIO: Okay, so you know when you're in the check-out lane at the grocery store and see your favorite candy next to the register?
ANTONIO: Even if you're on a budget, or a diet, you might just grab it. Because an impulse-buy can taste pretty good.
ANTONIO: Well, sometimes we make similar choices when it comes to drugs or alcohol. We just want something now, or feel like having fun.
ANTONIO: We might say "Just this once." And then, if nothing bad happens, "Okay, just one more time."
ANTONIO: And we might get away with it for a while.
ANTONIO: But if we keep it up, sooner or later we might hurt ourselves, or someone we care about.
ANTONIO: Of course, we don't plan for bad things to happen in our lives. No one wakes up on a beautiful Friday morning saying, "I think I'll get a DUI today!"
ANTONIO: We may think we are only choosing to have one more beer, to get high, or to have fun with our friends. We don't choose the problems. Why would we?
ANTONIO: And because we never plan to experience problems...
ANTONIO: We're likely to believe that when bad things do happen, it's a fluke.
ANTONIO: But over time, we can lose the things that are most important to us.
ANTONIO: I might hurt my career. My health could deteriorate. My friends and family may leave.
DUSTIN, US ARMY SOLDIER: Cause no one ever thinks about that when they start using, no one ever thinks about what they can lose.
DUSTIN, US ARMY SOLDIER: I mean they do to some extent, like oh I might get in trouble or go to jail.
DUSTIN, US ARMY SOLDIER: But they never will be like well I could be the direct result of my little sister dying in a car crash that I was driving the car and drinking.
ANTONIO: If we want to keep the things we love, we have to make choices that protect them. And that might take a new kind of thinking.
ANTONIO: We already do this in a lot of ways. You know how we change the oil in our cars to keep the engine working? Or... it's just like brushing our teeth every day.
ANTONIO: In this course, we're going to explore how to make similar choices with drugs and alcohol. Choices that protect the things we value most.
